There are 3 win conditions: point, military and science

- Military is skewed in favor of the player with the most resources since that player will be able to buy the best/most cards and it's easy to stop a player from doing it so it's not a real win condition.
- Science is easy to stop so it's not a real win condition
- Point is skewed in favor of the player with the most resources since that player will be able to buy the best/most cards

Duel solves some of my problems with the original 7 Wonders, and introduces a whole suit of new ones in the process.

The teaching is still a bit laborious given the minimalism of the gameplay. The playtime still assumes a brisk pace, but while the decision tree is larger than the original (more wonders, more lookahead of future plays), you're not limited by the slowest of up to 7 players for every single move. Guild cards are still a bit naff in their swinginess, but that the game is zero-sum, counterpicking and discarding for money what's favourable to your opponent is a viable option here. The tech tree is less of a bother, because there are fewer cards and you see the overwhelming majority of the deck first-hand every single game. The more convoluted scoring has been replaced by alternate paths to instant victory and small special power unlocks, and player interaction skyrockets from pretending it exists to being all the game is about.

Unfortunately, the kind of interaction the game is all about isn't super thrilling, which stems from two problems.

Firstly, two coins turns out to not be a massive consolation prize for discarding, and the game (or at least the early-to-mid-game, until one player is strong in yellow cards) is as such still skewed towards building your engine. On one hand, I understand this, because Duels would otherwise be a bloodbath of aggressive counterpicks running contrary to the intended engine build design. On the other hand, as a result, there doesn't seem to be a lot of the liminal scenarios between picking a card to build because it's the best/cheapest for you and picking a card to discard because your opponent getting it is far worse than you getting your best personal-to-build option.

More importantly, the game is zugzwang-heavy and very Nim-like, in that for any given card, one player is guaranteed to have control over getting dibs on it if they wish so. (My first session involved a military victory early into the second age that my opponent couldn't find a way to prevent. This was an unusually unlucky deal, but is indicative of less drastic versions of the problem in more regular games.) This is in theory tempered in two ways. The first one, which I think is the correct approach, is the proportion of wonders that grant an extra turn, allowing you to reverse the Nim scenario at will once you can build the wonder. (The theology science token I'm far less keen on, because managing to grab it is essentially already a reward for being advantaged by turn order.) It is, however, a once-per-game event, that guarantees pick on one card, but that the opponent can flip back later, and then it becomes a war on who has the most of this type of effect. The second solution - no doubt devised to steer the game as far away from combinatorial as possible - is to deal half the cards face down until uncovered. And that's where I think the entire game crumbles, because a too large amount of the plays essentially essentially come bundled with a swingy die roll about how much your opponent just got a free meal from you just revealed for them. A feature which... is also subject to the zugzwang nature of the game.

For the first few games, this felt like chess with multiple paths to victory. For each move there is at least one counter-move; and you can win with military supremacy, scientific supremacy, or a civilian victory in points. The main feature is the innovative facedown/faceup central draft structure that keeps cards locked in until unlocked, which introduces heavy elements of both hate-drafting and force-revealing. Strategic discarding and trashing has rarely been so important. And it has a GREAT insert. And yet. Despite my initial enjoyment, the game became a bit samey and confrontational, much like chess (apologies, chess fans!), as we developed heuristics and a meta which made the interesting-ness (read: difficulty) of the decisions drop away precipitously. The military and science strategies became more defensive annoyances and distraction tactics than legitimate paths, unless you had specific Wonders, and usually even then. Caveat: There are a lot of icons, which will take a game to internalise. Full disclosure, I find the back and forth of tug-of-war games to be quite tedious, hence my aversion to area majority (with some notable exceptions).

For such a complicated game, the instructions are really, really bad.

Positives: I like the addition of instant-win conditions (military and science), and the card stack revelation is a neat idea: more planning and less chance-based. Trading with bank is also good (though pricing is bizarre thematically-speaking). I also like how free builds are now indicated by icon instead of by text - much better interface than the original 7 Wonders!

Negatives: I still find the game more tactical than strategic (often making 2-way comparison choices, and just computing, which means much of the gameplay is simple computation), though the card revelation does mitigate this by adding a nice planning-ahead component which the original lacked. Still a few too many icons for my taste, but better than the original in this regard too.

Conclusion: If you like the original, you'll probably like this one and vice-versa. This one's a bit better if you want more strategy/planning, but in practice it will be decided by player count.

7 Wonders: Duel is the attempt to make 7 Wonders into a better game than the 2-player variant included with the main game. As with most people, I definitely see this as a success. In fact, I like it a lot more than 7 Wonders. The main reason for this, is that it keeps the basics of 7 Wonders (drafting, resources, military, science, guilds, unique wonders, etc.) but amps up the tension of the game. How does it do this?

-Instead of Science and Millitary just being VP paths in 7WD, they can instantly end the game in victory for the person that focuses on it.

-The pool drafting of where there are some cards face-down and some face-up (and how these are flipped up) can be really nerve wracking. Especially when opponents are going for Military/Science victory.

-Resource management is even trickier since resources opponents acquire make your deficiencies in those specific resources, more expensive to deal with.

-Each player starts with 4 wonders each. That said, the game is called 7 Wonders for a reason... As soon as a player builds their fourth Wonder, that denies their opponent from ever building their fourth.

The replay value of this game is fairly decent. You don't use all of the science progress markers, guilds or wonders each game. There are also 3 cards randomly removed from the 3 age decks. This is my one negative of the game. It can be disappointing to learn that you were planning on going for Science/Military victory and that option is not really available to you based on the cards randomly removed from the deck. Overall, this is decent 2-player game. There are other 2-player game I prefer.

You draft one card at a time on your turn, either paying for and taking its listed benefit, selling it for coins, or playing it face down as a resource towards one of four wonders. The structure and iconography takes after 7 Wonders, but reconfigures the deck and victory conditions for a 2p contest. Two resource types get axed. You draft four wonders each at the start. You can now win instantly by having nine more military symbols than your opponent, or collecting a set of six science symbols. You take it in turns to draft from a shared and mostly open pyramid of cards, and some wonders give you two turns in a row.

Some problems linger from 7 Wonders. Blue cards suck. You need resources late, but fight for them early, and new players will have no idea which to prioritise. A small number of strategies dominate. Coins feel too abundant. Aggressive yellow and brown card play, and science victories, seem favoured. But the new routes to victory enliven the setting and tension. I miss them in 7 Wonders. Sadly, the player count kills it for me. You'd want to play this a lot with the same worthy opponent(s), and I likely won't. I find myself on the fence about the original game. Welcome to 7 Wonders Duel the head-to-head version of the classic 7 Wonders and other like 20+ different versions but we don't talk about that XD. It's built entirely for two players. It’s all the glory, none of the waiting for six other people to finish drafting. If you like building civilizations, flexing your ancient empire’s power, and maybe crushing your opponent under the weight of your perfectly crafted wonders than this game is for you!

The game plays out over three Ages, each packed with cards that can boost your resources, military strength, or scientific progress. You’ll use these to grow your civilization, unlock powerful wonders, and (hopefully) leave your opponent in the historical dust.

Here’s the twist instead of drafting cards at the same time like in the original, both players pick from a pyramid style layout of face-up and face-down cards. You can only grab a card if it isn’t covered by another, so timing and planning are everything. Sometimes you’ll even get a bonus move that lets you snatch another card right away a perfect moment to ruin your opponent’s day.

There are three ways to win:
Military victory push your army all the way to your opponent’s capital. Instant win.
Scientific victory collect six of seven unique science symbols. Boom, brainpower triumphs.
Civilization victory if neither side dominates militarily or scientifically, you tally up points and see who history remembers.

Whether you’re conquering cities, building wonders, or outsmarting your rival with a single perfectly timed grab, 7 Wonders Duel is pure, intense, chess... like thing XD, fast, clever, and oh so satisfying when your opponent realizes you’ve just snatched their victory right out from under them.

Kurzrezension:
"7 Wonders Duel" ist der kleine Bruder des ersten 'Kennerspiel des Jahres': "7 Wonders". Das ursprüngliche Spiel hatte ebenfalls einen Zweispielermodus, der aber nicht wirklich funktionierte. Die Mechanismen der Duellvariante sind ganz anders und doch sehr ähnlich!

Spielablauf:
Vor der ersten Runde werden acht Weltwunder zwischen den beiden Spielern gedraftet. Im Verlauf des Spiels dürfen aber nur sieben davon errichtet werden.
Pro Spielrunde werden Kartenreihen ausgelegt, wobei Karten der unteren Reihen über denen vorheriger Reihen liegen. Der aktive Spieler darf immer nur freie Karten nehmen, also diejenigen, auf der keine andere Karte liegt. Liegen nach dem Nehmen verdeckte Karten frei, werden diese sofort aufgedeckt.
Beim Nehmen passieren verschiedene Effekte:
- Gelbe Karten erwirtschaften meist Gold oder vergünstigen den Ressourcenkauf.
- Braune und graue Karten stellen Ressourcen zur Verfügung, die wiederum zum Bau von blauen (Siegpunkte), grünen (Wissenschaft) oder roten (Militär) Karten gebraucht werden.
Die genommene Karte kann entweder in die eigene Auslage gelegt, für Münzen abgeworfen oder mit ihr ein Weltwunder errichtet werden. Sobald die letzte Karte aus der Auslage genommen wurde, endet das Zeitalter und das nächste wird aufgebaut.
Das Spiel kann auf drei Arten enden: Nachdem das dritte Zeitalter, also die dritte Kartenauslage durchgespielt ist, gewinnt der Spieler mit den meisten Punkten. Vorzeitig ist es zu Ende, wenn ein Spieler eine bestimmte Menge Militärsymbole sammeln konnte und seinen Gegner damit überrumpelt. Die dritte Möglichkeit besteht im Wissenschaftlichen-Sieg, wenn es einem Spieler gelingt sechs verschiedene Wissenschaftssymbole zu ergattern.

Erweiterungen:
Die erste Erweiterung "Pantheon" fügt dem Spiel Götter hinzu. Sie werden in einer Auslage oberhalb des zentralen Spielbretts gelegt und können mit den neuen Aktionen beeinflusst werden, womit sie dann dem entsprechenden Spieler Vorteile im Spiel bringen. Diese Aktionen liegen auf den verdeckten Karten des zweiten und dritten Zeitalters. Immer derjenige, der ein Aufdecken provoziert, erhält die Gunst der Götter, was die Wahl der Karten noch spannender macht!
Für Anfängerrunden stellen diese erweiterten Optionen aber zu viel Möglichkeiten zur Verfügung. Daher kann ich nur eine Empfehlung für geübte Spieler des Grunddspiels aussprechen.

Die zweite Erweiterung "Agora" bringt Politik ins Spiel. Dazu wird unterhalb des zentralen Spielbretts ein Politikbrett ausgelegt. Auf ihm sind Parlamentsmitglieder, die von den Spielern mit einer neuen Kartenart beeinflusst werden können. Zusätzlich bietet die Politik eine neue Siegmöglichkeit, wenn es einem Spieler gelingt alle Politiker zur gleichen Zeit auf die eigene Seite gezogen zu haben, was nicht einfach, aber durchaus möglich ist.
Diese Erweiterung ist ebenfalls nicht für Anfänger geeignet, da sie sogar noch mehr Optionen wie die Erste bietet. Kenner und Experten bietet sie aber noch mehr Abwechslung und Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten, die für den eigenen Spielzug berücksichtigt werden müssen. Immerhin muss eine zusätzliche Siegmöglichkeit im Blick behalten werden.
Ich fand sehr lange das Grundspiel, so wie es ist, völlig ausreichend. Nachdem ich aber noch einige Partien mehr gespielt habe, empfinde ich die beiden Erweiterungen durchaus gut und nehme eine der beiden, manchmal sogar beide sehr gerne mit hinein, wenn mein Gegenüber ebenfalls ein Kenner des Grundspiels ist.
Für mich zwei sehr gelungene Erweiterungen eines sehr guten Grundspiels.

Meinung:
"7 Wonders Duel" ist wohl eines, wenn nicht sogar das beste Zweispielerspiel in meinem Spielschrank.
Es nutzt den von mir geliebten Draftmechanismus auf eine vollkommen neue und für zwei Spieler gut funktionierende Art. Zudem sind die Effekte der Karten und die Matrix in der diese ausliegen so abgestimmt, dass es immer wieder spannend ist, welche Karte ich aus der Auslage nehme und welche ich damit meinem Gegner zur Verfügung stelle. Hinzu kommen die recht teuren Wunder, die ebenfalls errichtet werden können und sehr mächtige Bonnies zur Verfügung stellen.
Mir gefällt das Spiel außerordentlich gut und ich schlage keine Partie aus, wenn sich eine Gelegenheit dazu ergibt.
Die beiden Erweiterungen fügen dem Grundspiel weitere Optionen hinzu, die ich nur Spielern empfehlen kann, die das Grundspiel bereits sehr gut bis auswendig kennen.
"7 Wonders Duel" ist perfekt. Ich liebe es!
